name: An act relating to funding for the Vermont Internet Crimes Against Children (VT-ICAC) Task Force
description: Appropriates funds for the Vermont Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force and creates three staff positions.
reasoning: This bill only appropriates funds for the Vermont Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force and creates staff positions. It is purely procedural/administrative and does not establish any regulatory requirements for platforms, schools, or other entities regarding child online safety mechanisms.

name: Consumer Data Protection Act;  protections for children, definition of verifiable parental consent
description: Requires parental consent for minor accounts with services that process data, or to collect and use minors' data;  prohibits sale of minors' personal data, or using it for targeted advertising. Raises age of majority in existing data protection law to 18.
reasoning: Bill explicitly requires parental consent for minor accounts and data processing. It restricts data collection by prohibiting sale of minors' personal data and use for targeted advertising. Applies to services that process data generally, not specific platform categories. No mention of age verification requirements, algorithmic restrictions, duty of care standards, risk assessments, default privacy settings, or school-based measures.

name: Consumer Data Protection Act;  protections for children.
description: Requires parental consent for minor accounts with services that process data, or to collect and use minors' data;  prohibits sale of minors' personal data, or using it for targeted advertising. Raises age of majority in existing data protection law to 18.
reasoning: Bill explicitly requires parental consent for minor accounts and data processing, prohibits sale of minors' personal data and targeted advertising (data collection limits), and applies to services that process data generally (all platforms). No mention of age verification requirements, algorithmic restrictions, duty of care standards, risk assessments, default privacy settings, or school-based measures.

name: Civil liability for publishing or distributing material harmful to minors on the Internet
description: Requires age verification to access websites that are more than one-third pornography, excluding interactive computer services.  Raises age of majority in existing data protection law to 18.
reasoning: Bill requires age verification for pornography websites (>1/3 pornographic content) and raises age of majority to 18 in data protection law, creating data collection limits. Excludes interactive computer services, so doesn't target all platforms. No mention of parental consent, algorithmic restrictions, duty of care, risk assessments, default privacy settings, or school-based measures.

name: Providing online privacy protection laws for children under 18 years of age
description: Requires online services to obtain parental consent to collect, use, or disclose minors' personal information;  encourages creation of self-regulatory guidelines.
reasoning: Bill explicitly requires parental consent for collecting/using minors' personal information and restricts data collection practices for minors under 18. Applies broadly to online services. Self-regulatory guidelines are encouraged but not mandated. No requirements for age verification, algorithmic restrictions, or other mechanisms.

name: Relating to online privacy protection for minors
description: Prohibits internet services from advertising or marketing harmful products (incl. weapons, tobacco, lottery tickets, pornography, spray paint) to minors;  requires internet services to facilitate the removal of minors' posted content when requested.
reasoning: The bill prohibits advertising/marketing harmful products to minors and requires content removal capabilities, but does not explicitly mandate any of the specific mechanisms like age verification, parental consent, or data restrictions. It applies broadly to 'internet services' rather than specific categories, making it target all platforms.

name: Protection of minors from harmful material on internet
description: Requires age verification to access websites that are more than one-third pornography. Retaining ID information prohibited.
reasoning: Bill requires age verification for websites that are more than one-third pornography (specific category, not all platforms). It prohibits retaining ID information, which is a data collection/retention limit. No other mechanisms are explicitly required.

name: Relating to the Consumer Data Protection Act and establishing a framework for controlling and processing personal data in the State
description: General data privacy bill that categorizes all personal data relating to children as "sensitive".
reasoning: This is a general data privacy bill that categorizes children's personal data as 'sensitive', which typically creates restrictions on collection, use, and processing of such data. As a Consumer Data Protection Act, it would apply broadly to all platforms that process personal data, not just specific categories. However, the description doesn't indicate explicit requirements for age verification, parental consent mechanisms, algorithmic restrictions, or other specific child safety measures beyond the data protection classification.

name: Relating to: prostitution crime surcharge and making an appropriation.
description: Establishes a new fine and appropriates the revenue for investigating and prosecuting Internet crimes against children.
reasoning: This bill only establishes a fine/surcharge and appropriates revenue for investigating and prosecuting Internet crimes against children. It is a funding mechanism for law enforcement activities, not a regulatory framework that imposes requirements on platforms, schools, or other entities regarding child online safety mechanisms.

name: Relating to: pupil or minor access to harmful material in public libraries and to harmful material or offensive material in public schools.
description: Requires schools and libraries to use filters or otherwise prevent minors and students accessing pornography.
reasoning: Bill requires schools and libraries to use filters to prevent minors from accessing pornography. This is school/library-based filtering rather than platform regulation, and targets specific harmful content (pornography) rather than all platforms.
